test.sectiondirections: This section tests your understanding of conversations and lectures. You will hear each conversation or lecture only once. Your answers should be based on what is stated or implied in the conversations and lectures. You are allowed to take notes as you listen, and you can use these notes to help you answer the questions. In some questions, you will see a headphones icon. This icon tells you that you will hear, but not read, part of the lecture again. Then you will answer a question about the part of the lecture that you heard. Some questions have special directions that are highlighted. This test includes two conversations and four lectures. You must give an answer for every question, and then click NEXT. To confirm your answer, click OK. Once the next question appears, you cannot go back to earlier questions.

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: Why does Amy NOT plan to try out for the basketball team?
question.choice: She doesn't have any experience playing basketball.
The university doesn't have a women's basketball team.
She doesn't think that she is tall enough.
It's too late to try out for the team this year.

question.questiontext: What can be inferred about the fencing team's captain, Wendy Travis?
question.choice: She was a walk-on when she tried out for the team.
She won a scholarship the first year she was on the team.
She transferred to the university from another school.
She was recruited to the team by Ms. Wagner.

question.questiontext: According to the conversation, what quality does Ms. Wagner think is MOST important in a fencer?
question.choice: Speed
Physical strength
Willingness to learn
Intelligence

question.questiontext: How often does the fencing team practice during tryouts?
question.choice: Once a week
Twice a week
Three times a week
Four times a week

question.questiontext: What does Ms. Wagner suggest that Amy buy on the Internet?
question.choice: A mask
A glove
A jacket
A weapon

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: Why does Larry want to talk with Professor Kemp?
question.choice: To ask her to help him with his acting
To find out which play will be staged in the spring
To discuss his performance in her acting class
To make an appointment to audition for a play

question.questiontext: Why does Professor Kemp NOT want to direct the play Our Town?
question.choice: It would not involve any work for students interested in costumes and scenery.
She does not have the necessary background to direct this play.
She has never liked any of the plays written by Thornton Wilder.
This play is more appropriate for high school students than for university students.

question.boxtext: Listen again to part of the lecture.
question.questiontext: What does the professor mean when she says this? <icon>
question.choice: She will be unable to attend the Shakespeare festival this year.
She would like to direct a play written by Shakespeare every year.
She doesn't understand Larry's comment about Shakespeare.
She thinks that it's time to stage a play not written by Shakespeare.

question.questiontext: When does the action in the play The Crucible take place?
question.choice: In medieval times
In the seventeenth century
In the 1950s
In the present

question.questiontext: Why does Larry mention the plays Death of a Salesman and The Glass Menagerie?
question.choice: They are plays that he would like to see sometime soon.
They are plays that he would like Professor Kemp to direct.
They are plays that his roommate would like to be in.
They are plays by Arthur Miller that he is familiar with.

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: How does the professor describe the Great Red Spot?
question.choice: By explaining how its color is similar to the color of familiar objects
By contrasting it with features found on planets other than Earth
By comparing it to storms that occur on the planet Earth
By discussing the damage that it has caused on the planet Jupiter

question.questiontext: According to the professor, which of the following facts about the Great Red Spot is definitely true?
question.choice: It was discovered by the Italian astronomer Cassini.
It first formed about 350 years ago.
It will last for only a few more years.
It was first observed in the seventeenth century.

question.questiontext: What chemical probably causes the Great Red Spot to appear red?
question.choice: Phosphorous
Hydrogen
Methane
Helium

question.questiontext: How do white ovals in the atmosphere of Jupiter differ from brown ovals?
question.choice: White ovals are storms, but brown ovals are not.
The winds in brown ovals are stronger than those in white ovals.
White ovals last only for a few hours, but brown ovals last for decades.
The clouds in brown ovals are warmer than those in white ovals.

question.questiontext: In this lecture, the professor gives a number of characteristics of the Great Red Spot and Oval BA (Red Junior). Indicate whether each of the following is a characteristic of that feature.
question.heading: The Great Red Spot
Oval BA (Red Junior)
question.choice: Was formed by the joining of three ovals
Is the size of three planets as big as Earth
Changed from white to brown to red in a few months
May cause the other feature to slow down

question.questiontext: What does the professor imply when he says this? <icon>
question.choice: The moons of Jupiter are more interesting than the Great Red Spot.
There are also giant storms on the planet Neptune.
He's decided that he is not going to discuss Neptune next week.
There may be storms like the Great Red Spot on Jupiter's moons.

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: What are the students primarily doing?
question.choice: Preparing to give a presentation
Writing a research paper
Getting ready for an examination
Filling out a laboratory report

question.questiontext: If an animal has an exoskeleton, where is the thinnest part of its outer skeleton?
question.choice: On its back
On its eyes
On its legs
On its head

question.questiontext: What are two advantages of an exoskeleton?
question.choice: It provides some animals with special tools such as a stinger.
It allows animals to grow to a larger size.
It is lightweight compared to an endoskeleton.
It protects animals from injury.

question.questiontext: Why does the man mention sharks?
question.choice: Sharks have skeletons made of chitin.
Sharks' skeletons are not as streamlined as those of most fish.
Sharks have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.
Sharks developed later than most types of fish.

question.questiontext: In this discussion, the students give a number of characteristics of fish bones, bird bones, and mammal bones. Indicate which of the following sentences is a characteristic of each type of bone.
question.heading: Fish bones
Bird bones
Mammal bones
question.choice: Are so thin that light passes through them
Are the thickest, strongest, and heaviest bones
Are hollow but are strengthened by crosswalls
Have no marrow cavity

question.boxtext: Listen again to part of the discussion.
question.questiontext: What does the woman mean when she says this? <icon>
question.choice: The information is difficult to understand.
The picture contains several mistakes.
The print on the illustration is too small.
The man doesn't need to get another book.

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: What is the main purpose of this lecture?
question.choice: To compare drums and other types of instruments
To describe one type of percussion instrument
To speculate about the early history of drums
To contrast drummers in the past with those of today

question.questiontext: According to the speaker, where were the first drums of any kind used?
question.choice: Persia
Hungary
Africa
Rome

question.questiontext: How does the speaker explain the concept of talking drums?
question.choice: By comparing then to several other types of drums
By providing an example of messages they might send
By imitating the sounds that these drums might make
By comparing them to a modern communication system

question.questiontext: Which of the following is NOT true about kettle drums?
question.choice: They are the largest of all drums.
They were once played by foot, but today are played by hand.
They are shaped like large bowls.
They are the only drums that can be tuned to a specific note.

question.questiontext: Which of these drums are part of a standard five-drum set?
question.choice: Snare drum
Tom-toms
Tympani
Bass drum
Tenor drum

question.questiontext: What is the speaker's opinion of rock and roll drummers of the 1960s?
question.choice: They were not as talented as earlier drummers.
They used too many drums in their drum set.
They were better known than earlier drummers.
They had more formal training than drummers today.

question.highlightbox:
Now get ready to answer the questions.
You may use your notes to help you.
question.questiontext: Why does the professor mention Samoans in this discussion?
question.choice: Samoans speak to newborn babies as if they were adults.
Samoans do not directly speak to babies until they are one year old.
Samoan babies learn to speak sooner than babies in other cultures.
Samoans use an extreme form of child-directed speech.

question.questiontext: In this discussion, the professor explains the concept of child-directed speech (CDS) in a number of ways. Indicate whether each of the following is one of the methods that the professor uses to explain this concept.
question.heading: Yes
No
question.choice: She imitates some typical CDS sentences.
She plays a recording of a parent using CDS.
She mentions a more familiar name for CDS.
She compares CDS to normal speech.

question.boxtext: Listen again to part of the conversation.
question.questiontext: What does the professor mean when she says this? <icon>
question.choice: She mostly disagrees with the idea that parents teach babies to speak.
She has no idea how to answer the student's question.
She completely disagrees with the opinion that the student offers.
She agrees that parents teach babies to talk, but many experts don't.

question.questiontext: What can be inferred about Grace's baby nephew from the lecture?
question.choice: He does not really mean "mama" when he says this word.
His mother wants him to take part in a language-learning experiment.
He has already learned the meaning of several words.
His expressive language skills are better than his receptive language skills.

question.questiontext: Which of the following is an example of a holophrastic phase?
question.choice: Na, na.
Want more milk.
Kitty!
Hi, mama!

question.questiontext: What does Professor Jordan say about the grammatical mistakes that children make?
question.choice: They are learned by imitating the mistakes that adults make.
They are generally misinterpreted by parents.
They are often logical errors caused by "overlearning" grammar.
They are the same mistakes no matter what language children speak.

test.sectionClosing: This is the end of the Listening Section of Practice Test 4. You may take a ten-minute break before beginning work on the Speaking Section.
